Numerical Algorithms for the Computation of Generalized Prolate Spheroidal Functions

Roy R. Lederman
The Program in Applied and Computational Mathematics
Princeton University
Abstract

Generalized Prolate Spheroidal Functions (GPSF) are the eigenfunctions of the truncated Fourier transform, restricted to D-dimensional balls in the spatial domain and frequency domain. Despite their useful properties in many applications, GPSFs are often replaced by crude approximations. The purpose of this paper is to review the elements of computing GPSFs and associated eigenvalues. This paper is accompanied by open-source code.

Keywords: Generalized Prolate Spheroidal Functions, GPSF, PSWF, Truncated Fourier Transform, Implementation.

1 Introduction

Prolate Spheroidal Wave Functions (PSWF), the one-dimensional case of the GPSFs discussed in this paper, are the eigenfunctions of the truncated Fourier transform Fcsubscriptğ¹ğ‘F_{c}, defined by the formula

(Fcâ€‹Ïˆ)â€‹(x)=âˆ«âˆ’11eiâ€‹câ€‹xâ€‹yâ€‹Ïˆâ€‹(y)â€‹ğ‘‘y,subscriptğ¹ğ‘ğœ“ğ‘¥superscriptsubscript11superscriptğ‘’iğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğœ“ğ‘¦differential-dğ‘¦\left(F_{c}\psi\right)(x)=\int_{-1}^{1}e^{\mathrm{i}cxy}\psi(y)dy, (1)

with xâˆˆ[âˆ’1,1]ğ‘¥11x\in[-1,1]. In the classic work [18] by Slepian and Pollak it has been shown that the integral operator Fcâˆ—â€‹Fcsuperscriptsubscriptğ¹ğ‘subscriptğ¹ğ‘F_{c}^{*}F_{c} commutes with the differential operator Lcsubscriptğ¿ğ‘L_{c} defined by the formula

(Lcâ€‹Ïˆ)â€‹(x)=(1âˆ’x2)â€‹d2dâ€‹x2â€‹Ïˆâ€‹(x)âˆ’2â€‹xâ€‹ddâ€‹xâ€‹Ïˆâ€‹(x)âˆ’c2â€‹x2â€‹Ïˆâ€‹(x).subscriptğ¿ğ‘ğœ“ğ‘¥1superscriptğ‘¥2superscriptğ‘‘2ğ‘‘superscriptğ‘¥2ğœ“ğ‘¥2ğ‘¥ğ‘‘ğ‘‘ğ‘¥ğœ“ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘2superscriptğ‘¥2ğœ“ğ‘¥\left(L_{c}\psi\right)(x)=(1-x^{2})\frac{d^{2}}{dx^{2}}\psi(x)-2x\frac{d}{dx}\psi(x)-c^{2}x^{2}\psi(x). (2)

This remarkable property was subsequently used to infer many of the properties of PSWFs and to develop efficient and accurate methods for computing them in [18, 20, 19, 13, 12, 10] among other works. This rare relation between an integral operator and a differential operator has been discovered and used for the analysis of the truncated Laplace transform as well (e.g. [2, 7, 10]).

In subsequent work in [17], Slepian discovered a similar relation associated with the general case of high dimensional Fourier transform, supported on the unit ball

(Fcâ€‹Ïˆ)â€‹(ğ’™)=âˆ«|ğ’š|â‰¤1eiâ€‹câ€‹(ğ’™â‹…ğ’š)â€‹Ïˆâ€‹(ğ’š)â€‹ğ‘‘ğ’š,subscriptğ¹ğ‘ğœ“ğ’™subscriptğ’š1superscriptğ‘’iğ‘â‹…ğ’™ğ’šğœ“ğ’šdifferential-dğ’š\left({F}_{c}\psi\right)({\bm{x}})=\int_{|{\bm{y}}|\leq 1}e^{\mathrm{i}c\left({\bm{x}}\cdot{\bm{y}}\right)}\psi(\bm{y}){d}\bm{y}, (3)

where ğ’šğ’š{\bm{y}} and ğ’™ğ’™{\bm{x}} are vectors in â„Dsuperscriptâ„ğ·\mathbb{R}^{D}, and |ğ’™|â‰¤1ğ’™1|{\bm{x}}|\leq 1 . The eigenfunctions of this operator are the GPSFs.

PSWFs have been useful in many applications in signal processing. Among their many useful properties, they are the optimal basis for representing functions whose energy is as concentrated as possible in the interval [âˆ’1,1]11[-1,1] in the spatial domain, and in the interval [âˆ’c,c]ğ‘ğ‘[-c,c] in the frequency domain. GPSFs are known to be useful in many applications in signal processing and optics, however they have gained a reputation of being prohibitively difficult to compute, and in practice they are often replaced by crude approximations.

The properties of GPSFs have been studied by Slepian in [17]. Many of the properties of the two-dimensional GPSFs, have been studied in [15, 16]. Recently, the more general GPSFs have been studied in [14], and they are being studied in the upcoming [3]. However, we are not aware of a complete publicly available resource and code for efficient and accurate computation of GPSFs and their associated eigenvalues.

The purpose of this paper is to review the essential results for computing GPSFs, and to introduce numerical code for computing GPSFs. We review results primarily from [17, 15] and [14], with some reformulation and generalization, as well as some unpublished results which Philip Greengard and Kirill Serkh have been generous to share with us from their upcoming [3], and introduce additional results.

The immediate motivation for this paper is the use of three-dimensional GPSFs for representing objects that are highly concentrated in both the spatial and frequency domains in cryo-electron microscopy (cryo-EM) applications (e.g. [8, 9]). Indeed the two-dimensional GPSFs have been used successfully for the representation of images in cryo-EM in [4, 5].

A MATLABTM source code is available at http://github.com/lederman/prol together with the LaTeX source for this paper. FORTRAN code is under development. In addition, the URL above contains MathematicaTM code which performs various levels of analytic verification of some of the equations in this paper after they have been derived in other means (an â€œopen-source proofâ€).

The current paper and code are preliminary results of the ongoing project in http://github.com/lederman/prol. We welcome comments and contributions to the code and paper.

This paper is organized as follows. Section 2 briefly reviews standard definitions and results that are used in the paper. Section 3 presents the essential analytical results required for computing GPSFs. The algorithms based on these analytical results are presented in Section 5. Numerical results obtained with the publicly available code are presented in Section 6. Finally, brief conclusions are presented in 7.

3 Analytical Apparatus

3.1 The Truncated Fourier Transform and Associated Integral Operators

In this section we discuss standard definitions of the integral operators associated with GPSFs. A more detailed discussion of the operators can be found in [17, 14].

The unitary Fourier integral transform â„±â„±\mathcal{F} in Dğ·D dimensions is defined by the formula

(â„±â€‹f)â€‹(ğ’™)=(12â€‹Ï€)D/2â€‹âˆ«â„Deiâ€‹ğ’™â‹…ğ’•â€‹fâ€‹(t)â€‹ğ‘‘ğ’•,â„±ğ‘“ğ’™superscript12ğœ‹ğ·2subscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ·superscriptğ‘’â‹…iğ’™ğ’•ğ‘“ğ‘¡differential-dğ’•\left(\mathcal{F}f\right)({\bm{x}})=\left(\frac{1}{2\pi}\right)^{D/2}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{D}}e^{\mathrm{i}{\bm{x}}\cdot{\bm{t}}}f(t){d}{\bm{t}}, (19)

where ğ’•ğ’•{\bm{t}} and ğ’™ğ’™{\bm{x}} are vectors, and ğ’™â‹…ğ’•=âˆ‘xiâ€‹tiâ‹…ğ’™ğ’•subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–{\bm{x}}\cdot{\bm{t}}=\sum{x_{i}t_{i}} is the usual inner product.

The truncate Fourier transform â„±c:L2â€‹(BD)â†’L2â€‹(câ€‹BD):subscriptâ„±ğ‘â†’superscriptğ¿2superscriptğµğ·superscriptğ¿2ğ‘superscriptğµğ·\mathcal{F}_{c}:L^{2}(B^{D})\rightarrow L^{2}(cB^{D}) is the restriction of the domain of the Fourier Transform to functions supported on the unit ball BDsuperscriptğµğ·B^{D} of dimension Dğ·D, centered at the origin, with the range truncated to the ball câ€‹BDğ‘superscriptğµğ·cB^{D} of radius cğ‘c,

â„±c=ğŸcâ€‹BDâ€‹â„±â€‹ğŸBD,subscriptâ„±ğ‘subscript1ğ‘superscriptğµğ·â„±subscript1superscriptğµğ·\mathcal{F}_{c}={\bm{1}}_{cB^{D}}\mathcal{F}{\bm{1}}_{B^{D}}, (20)

where ğŸBDsubscript1superscriptğµğ·{\bm{1}}_{B^{D}} is the restriction operator. In other words,

(â„±câ€‹f)â€‹(ğ’™)=(12â€‹Ï€)D/2â€‹âˆ«â€–ğ’•â€–â‰¤1eiâ€‹ğ’™â‹…ğ’•â€‹fâ€‹(t)â€‹ğ‘‘ğ’•,subscriptâ„±ğ‘ğ‘“ğ’™superscript12ğœ‹ğ·2subscriptnormğ’•1superscriptğ‘’â‹…iğ’™ğ’•ğ‘“ğ‘¡differential-dğ’•\left(\mathcal{F}_{c}f\right)({\bm{x}})=\left(\frac{1}{2\pi}\right)^{D/2}\int_{\|{\bm{t}}\|\leq 1}e^{\mathrm{i}{\bm{x}}\cdot{\bm{t}}}f(t){d}{\bm{t}}, (21)

with ğ’™ğ’™{\bm{x}} restricted to â€–ğ’™â€–â‰¤1normğ’™1\|{\bm{x}}\|\leq 1.

It is often convenient to scale the truncated Fourier transform to the form Fc:L2â€‹(BD)â†’L2â€‹(BD):subscriptğ¹ğ‘â†’superscriptğ¿2superscriptğµğ·superscriptğ¿2superscriptğµğ·{F}_{c}:L^{2}(B^{D})\rightarrow L^{2}(B^{D}) defined by the equation

(Fcâ€‹Ïˆ)â€‹(x)=âˆ«Beiâ€‹câ€‹(ğ’™â‹…ğ’•)â€‹Ïˆâ€‹(ğ’•)â€‹ğ‘‘ğ’•.subscriptğ¹ğ‘ğœ“ğ‘¥subscriptğµsuperscriptğ‘’iğ‘â‹…ğ’™ğ’•ğœ“ğ’•differential-dğ’•\left({F}_{c}\psi\right)(x)=\int_{B}e^{\mathrm{i}c\left({\bm{x}}\cdot{\bm{t}}\right)}\psi(\bm{t}){d}\bm{t}. (22)

In this form, the domain and range are the same function spaces. The goal of this paper is to discuss the computation of the GPSFs which are the eigenfunctions of the operator Fcsubscriptğ¹ğ‘{F}_{c}, and the associated eigenvalues, i.e. the functions Ïˆğœ“\psi and scalars Î±ğ›¼\alpha that satisfy

Î±â€‹Ïˆ=Fcâ€‹Ïˆ.ğ›¼ğœ“subscriptğ¹ğ‘ğœ“\alpha\psi={F}_{c}\psi. (23)

Let p=Dâˆ’2ğ‘ğ·2p=D-2, ğ’™=râ€‹ğƒğ’™ğ‘Ÿğƒ{\bm{x}}=r{\bm{\xi}} and ğ’š=râ€²â€‹ğ’ğ’šsuperscriptğ‘Ÿâ€²ğ’{\bm{y}}=r^{\prime}{\bm{n}}, where rğ‘Ÿr and râ€²superscriptğ‘Ÿâ€²r^{\prime} are non-negative real numbers, and ğƒğƒ{\bm{\xi}} and ğ’ğ’{\bm{n}} are unit vectors in Dğ·D dimensions. Substituting (22) into (23) with this change of variables yields

(Fcâ€‹Ïˆ)â€‹(râ€‹ğƒ)=Î±â€‹Ïˆâ€‹(râ€‹ğƒ)=âˆ«01ğ‘‘râ€²â€‹râ€²â£p+1â€‹âˆ«Î©eiâ€‹câ€‹râ€‹râ€²â€‹(ğƒâ‹…ğ’)â€‹Ïˆâ€‹(râ€²â€‹ğ’)â€‹ğ‘‘Î©â€‹(ğ’),subscriptğ¹ğ‘ğœ“ğ‘Ÿğƒğ›¼ğœ“ğ‘Ÿğƒsuperscriptsubscript01differential-dsuperscriptğ‘Ÿâ€²superscriptğ‘Ÿâ€²ğ‘1subscriptÎ©superscriptğ‘’iğ‘ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğ‘Ÿâ€²â‹…ğƒğ’ğœ“superscriptğ‘Ÿâ€²ğ’differential-dÎ©ğ’\left({F}_{c}\psi\right)(r{\bm{\xi}})=\alpha\psi(r{\bm{\xi}})=\int_{0}^{1}dr^{\prime}r^{\prime p+1}\int_{\Omega}e^{\mathrm{i}crr^{\prime}\left({\bm{\xi}}\cdot{\bm{n}}\right)}\psi(r^{\prime}\bm{n}){d}\Omega(\bm{n}), (24)

and suggests a separation of variables Ïˆâ€‹(râ€‹ğƒ)=Î¦â€‹(r)â€‹SNmâ€‹(ğƒ)ğœ“ğ‘ŸğƒÎ¦ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ğ‘šğƒ\psi(r{\bm{\xi}})=\Phi(r)S_{N}^{m}({\bm{\xi}}), such that

(25)

Substituting (17) into (25) yields

3.2 The Associated Differential Operator

In this section we summarize several properties of the differential operator Lp,c,Nsubscriptğ¿ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘L_{p,c,N}, defined by the formula

(Lp,c,Nâ€‹Ï†)â€‹(x)=(ddâ€‹xâ€‹(1âˆ’x2)â€‹ddâ€‹xâ€‹Ï†â€‹(x))+(1/4âˆ’(N+p/2)2x2âˆ’c2â€‹x2)â€‹Ï†â€‹(x).subscriptğ¿ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğœ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘‘ğ‘‘ğ‘¥1superscriptğ‘¥2ğ‘‘ğ‘‘ğ‘¥ğœ‘ğ‘¥14superscriptğ‘ğ‘22superscriptğ‘¥2superscriptğ‘2superscriptğ‘¥2ğœ‘ğ‘¥\left(L_{p,c,N}\varphi\right)(x)=\left(\frac{d}{dx}(1-x^{2})\frac{d}{dx}\varphi(x)\right)+\left(\frac{1/4-(N+p/2)^{2}}{x^{2}}-c^{2}x^{2}\right)\varphi(x). (34)

In the classic work in [17], Slepian found that the integral operator Mp,c,Nsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘M_{p,c,N}, defined in (33), commutes with the differential operator Lp,c,Nsubscriptğ¿ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘L_{p,c,N},

Mp,c,Nâ€‹Lp,c,Nâ€‹Ï†=Lp,c,Nâ€‹Mp,c,Nâ€‹Ï†,subscriptğ‘€ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘subscriptğ¿ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğœ‘subscriptğ¿ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘subscriptğ‘€ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğœ‘M_{p,c,N}L_{p,c,N}\varphi=L_{p,c,N}M_{p,c,N}\varphi, (35)

so that they share the same eigenfunctions (but not eigenvalues). The eigendecomposition of Lp,c,Nsubscriptğ¿ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘L_{p,c,N} is therefore

Lp,c,Nâ€‹Ï†N,n=Ï‡np,c,Nâ€‹Ï†N,n,subscriptğ¿ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘subscriptğœ‘ğ‘ğ‘›subscriptsuperscriptğœ’ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘›subscriptğœ‘ğ‘ğ‘›L_{p,c,N}\varphi_{N,n}=\chi^{p,c,N}_{n}\varphi_{N,n}, (36)

where Ï†N,nsubscriptğœ‘ğ‘ğ‘›\varphi_{N,n} are the same functions defined in (30), and Ï‡np,c,Nsubscriptsuperscriptğœ’ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘›\chi^{p,c,N}_{n} the eigenvalues of Lp,c,Nsubscriptğ¿ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘L_{p,c,N}.

It is convenient to refer to ÏˆN,n,msubscriptğœ“ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘š\psi_{N,n,m}, ÏˆN,n,m~~subscriptğœ“ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘š\widetilde{\psi_{N,n,m}} and Î½N,nsubscriptğœˆğ‘ğ‘›\nu_{N,n} as â€œeigenfunctionsâ€ and â€œeigenvaluesâ€ of the operator â„±csubscriptâ„±ğ‘\mathcal{F}_{c} because of their close relation to the eigenfunctions ÏˆN,n,msubscriptğœ“ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘š\psi_{N,n,m} and eigenvalues Î±N,n,Î²N,nsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘ğ‘›subscriptğ›½ğ‘ğ‘›\alpha_{N,n},\beta_{N,n} and Î³N,nsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘ğ‘›\gamma_{N,n}, although the domain of the operator â„±csubscriptâ„±ğ‘\mathcal{F}_{c} is different from its range.

For a given p,Nğ‘ğ‘p,N, and a growing cğ‘c, the magnitude |Î½N,n|subscriptğœˆğ‘ğ‘›|\nu_{N,n}| of the first few eigenvalues is very close to 111. In fact, as cğ‘c grows, there is a growing number of eigenvalues that are numerically indistinguishable from 111. After a certain number of eigenvalues that are very close to 111, the eigenvalues decay super-algebraically. Some examples are presented in the numerical results.

Consider the Fourier transform g=â„±â€‹ÏˆN,n,mğ‘”â„±subscriptğœ“ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘šg=\mathcal{F}\psi_{N,n,m} of a GPSF, and the truncated Fourier transform gc=â„±â€‹ÏˆN,n,msubscriptğ‘”ğ‘â„±subscriptğœ“ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘šg_{c}=\mathcal{F}\psi_{N,n,m}. Since the Fourier transform is a unitary operation, and the GPSF is normalized â€–ÏˆN,n,mâ€–22=1superscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptğœ“ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘š221\|\psi_{N,n,m}\|_{2}^{2}=1, we also have that

â€–â„±â€‹ÏˆN,n,mâ€–22=â€–gâ€–22=1.superscriptsubscriptnormâ„±subscriptğœ“ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘š22superscriptsubscriptnormğ‘”221\|\mathcal{F}\psi_{N,n,m}\|_{2}^{2}=\|g\|_{2}^{2}=1. (56)

Furthermore, since ÏˆN,n,msubscriptğœ“ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘š\psi_{N,n,m} is supported on the unit ball by definition, we also have that within the ball câ€‹BDğ‘superscriptğµğ·cB^{D} of band cğ‘c,

gâ€‹(ğ)=(â„±â€‹ÏˆN,n,m)â€‹(ğ)=gcâ€‹(ğ)=(â„±câ€‹ÏˆN,n,m)â€‹(ğ)=Î½N,nâ€‹ÏˆN,n,m~â€‹(ğ),â€–ğâ€–â‰¤c.formulae-sequenceğ‘”ğâ„±subscriptğœ“ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘šğsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘ğsubscriptâ„±ğ‘subscriptğœ“ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘šğsubscriptğœˆğ‘ğ‘›~subscriptğœ“ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘šğnormğğ‘g({\bm{\omega}})=\left(\mathcal{F}\psi_{N,n,m}\right)({\bm{\omega}})=g_{c}({\bm{\omega}})=\left(\mathcal{F}_{c}\psi_{N,n,m}\right)({\bm{\omega}})=\nu_{N,n}\widetilde{\psi_{N,n,m}}({\bm{\omega}})~{}~{},~{}~{}\|{\bm{\omega}}\|\leq c. (57)

Therefore,

â€–â„±câ€‹ÏˆN,n,mâ€–22=â€–gcâ€–22=|Î½N,n|2.superscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptâ„±ğ‘subscriptğœ“ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘š22superscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘22superscriptsubscriptğœˆğ‘ğ‘›2\|\mathcal{F}_{c}\psi_{N,n,m}\|_{2}^{2}=\|g_{c}\|_{2}^{2}=|\nu_{N,n}|^{2}. (58)

By definition, the function gcâ€‹(ğ)=(â„±câ€‹ÏˆN,n,m)â€‹(ğ)subscriptğ‘”ğ‘ğsubscriptâ„±ğ‘subscriptğœ“ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘šğg_{c}({\bm{\omega}})=\left(\mathcal{F}_{c}\psi_{N,n,m}\right)({\bm{\omega}}) is identically zero for â€–ğâ€–â‰¥cnormğğ‘\|{\bm{\omega}}\|\geq c. However, gâ€‹(ğ)ğ‘”ğg({\bm{\omega}}) cannot be identically zero on the outside due to classic results in analysis that assert that functions cannot be compactly supported in both the spatial domain and frequency domain. The amount of energy that persists outside the band cğ‘c is

â€–gâˆ’gcâ€–22=1âˆ’|Î½N,n|2.superscriptsubscriptnormğ‘”subscriptğ‘”ğ‘221superscriptsubscriptğœˆğ‘ğ‘›2\|g-g_{c}\|_{2}^{2}=1-|\nu_{N,n}|^{2}. (59)

It follows that the first few GPSFs, with eigenvalues very close to 111, are highly concentrated in both the spatial domain and the frequency domain. With a small abuse of terminology, we say that these functions are numerically compactly supported in both the spatial and frequency domains. Subsequent GPSFs with smaller eigenvalues have most of their energy concentrated outside the band cğ‘c. In this sense, the first few GPSFs, with eigenvalues close to 111, and a rather sharp threshold after which the eigenvalues become very small, are the optimal basis for representing functions that are highly concentrated in both the spatial and frequency domains.

5 Algorithms

5.1 Computation of GPSFs

The radial GPSFs, defined in (27), are obtained via the expansion (43), in the basis of normalized radial Zernike polynomials (defined in (8)). The coefficients of the expansion are the elements of the eigenvectors ğ’‰p,c,N,nsuperscriptğ’‰ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘›{\bm{h}}^{p,c,N,n} of the matrix BNp,csuperscriptsubscriptğµNp,cB_{\text{N}}^{\text{p,c}} defined in (38) and (37). The eigenvalues Ï‡0p,c,Nsubscriptsuperscriptğœ’ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘0\chi^{p,c,N}_{0} of the matrix BNp,csuperscriptsubscriptğµNp,cB_{\text{N}}^{\text{p,c}} are sorted so that they grow in magnitude. We note that it is not necessary in general to compute all the eigenvectors of the matrix, individual eigenvectors can be found analogously to the procedure in [6].

In the present paper we do not discuss the decay of the elements hkp,c,N,nsubscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘˜{h}^{p,c,N,n}_{k} of the eigenvectors in detail. These elements decay rapidly with kğ‘˜k, and the matrix BNp,csuperscriptsubscriptğµNp,cB_{\text{N}}^{\text{p,c}} can be truncated without loss of numerical precision. In the current implementation we simply ensure that the dimensions of BNp,csuperscriptsubscriptğµNp,cB_{\text{N}}^{\text{p,c}} are sufficiently large to ensure a sufficient number of eigenfunctions and a sufficiently long expansion; the appropriate truncation will be discussed in future papers.

The relation to the â€œeigenfunctionsâ€ of the more familiar unscaled Fourier transform if described in Section 4. The relation between these radial components of GPSFs and the GPSFs on the D-dimensional ball are discussed in Section 3.1.

Remark 2

Obviously, the GPSFs computed through the eigendecomposition above have a degree of freedom in their sign (if Î¦N,nâ€‹(x)subscriptÎ¦ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘¥\Phi_{N,n}(x) is a normalized eigenfunction, then âˆ’Î¦N,nâ€‹(x)subscriptÎ¦ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘¥-\Phi_{N,n}(x) is also a normalized eigenfunction). For the sake of consistency across different implementations, we remove the ambiguity by setting the sign of the first element h0p,c,N,nsubscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘›0{h}^{p,c,N,n}_{0} of the eigenvectors to be positive for even nğ‘›n and negative for odd nğ‘›n.

Remark 3

The sign standardization above, and the accurate computation of eigenvalues using (32) in the next section rely in some cases on obtaining relative precision in some elements of the eigenvectors ğ¡p,c,N,nsuperscriptğ¡ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘›{\bm{h}}^{p,c,N,n}. While relative precision can be obtained in the cases in question (see [11]), not all eigedecomposition algorithms achieve it.

5.2 Computation of the First Associated Eigenvalue

The first eigenvalue Î³N,0subscriptğ›¾ğ‘0\gamma_{N,0}, defined in (32), is computed using the relation (52), with n=0ğ‘›0n=0. Alternatively, it can often be computed via (31) by numerical integration.

5.3 Computation of Associated Eigenvalues

The expansion ğ’‰p,c,N,n~~superscriptğ’‰ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘›\widetilde{{\bm{h}}^{p,c,N,n}} of xâ€‹Î¦N,nâ€²â€‹(x)ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptÎ¦ğ‘ğ‘›â€²ğ‘¥x\Phi_{N,n}^{\prime}(x) such that

6 Numerical Results

The algorithms describe above have been implemented in MATLABTM. The following figures are examples of GPSFs and associated eigenvalues. The code for reproducing these plots is available at http://github.com/lederman/prol.

Remark 4

For the sake of simplicity, the current MATLABTM implementation makes use of MATLABâ€™s â€œeigâ€ eigendecomposition. This subroutine retains relative precision only in certain elements, but not in all elements, as discussed in Remark 3. The truncation is corrected for certain computations using an inverse power method step on the first eigenvector. For this reason and other reasons, future implementations will replace the eigendecomposition procedure.

7 Conclusions

In this paper we reviewed the essential results for numerical computation of the eigenfunctions of the truncated Fourier transform, which is restricted to the unit ball in the spatial domain and band-limited in the frequency domain. The paper is accompanied by an example implementation, available as an open-source project at http://github.com/lederman/prol.

The code and paper are preliminary results of the ongoing project in http://github.com/lederman/prol. A more comprehensive code in additional languages is being developed. We welcome comments and contributions to both the code and the text through the open-source project.
